aAMDSx-y6.memHandModelNotes: May range far from streams at high elevations (>1370?? (elevation taken from D. ocoee)).  Use 30 m stream buffer <1370 and 60 m >1370.

references.B98PET01NCGP: Petranka, J. W. 1998. Salamanders of the United States and Canada. Washington DC: Smithsonian Inst. Press.
references.B05PAU02USGP: Pauley, T.K. and M.B. Watson. 2005. Desmognathus ochrophaeus (Cope, 1859). Allegheny Dusky Mountain Salamander. In Lannoo (Ed.), Amphibian Declines. The Conservation Status of United States Species, University of California Press, Berkeley, CA. p. 716-719.
references.A96TIL01NAUS: Tilley, S. G., and M. J. Mahoney. 1996. Patterns of genetic differentiation in salamanders of the DESMOGNATHUS OCHROPHAEUS complex (Amphibia:Plethodontidae). Herpetological Monographs 10:1-41.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

habitat_description: Found near stream margins and on wet, mossy rockfaces in moist, mesic woodlands, usually hardwoods or mixed pine-hardwoods (Wilson 1995).  At high elevations, they may be found far from running water (Petranka 1998). They occupy moister habitats closer to stremsn than eastern red-backed salamanders in areas of co-occurrence. Juveniles are often found under forest litter immediately adjacent to first-order streams (Pauley and Watson 2005).
